Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Retrospective application for amendments to previous planning permission ref 22/02784/HOU including increase to  height of rear extension roof by creation of small low level parapet, alteration to the new dormer size and its placement as well as removal of the rear Juliet balcony door and replacement with a window.Consultations6 properties were notified of the proposal.  Two representations (from one postal address) have been received objecting to the proposal, with comments summarised as follows:- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Loss of light/Sunlight- PrivacyOfficer comment: The above concerns will be addressed with this report. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note the relevant planning history:22/02784/HOU for Demolition of existing conservatory and erection of part single, two-storey rear extension. Rear piggyback roof extension with 2no side dormers to facilitate loft conversion. Installation of 100mm external wall insulation to front and left elevations. Associated changes to fenestration - Granted on 12.10.2022.Officers note the retrospective character of the current application.The main differences between the approved application  22/02784/HOU and the current submission is the proposed total height of the single storey rear extension from approximately 2.7 to 3.2m (including parapet roof), the addition of fixed and obscure glazed windows to the side elevation, alterations to the side dormers and replacement of the rear Juliet balcony door with a window.As the principle of the development as well as the character and appearance of the proposal has been established under the previous planning application  22/02784/HOU, Officers will assess the current changes to the proposal. The proposed increase of the total height of the single storey rear extension from approximately 2.7m to 3.2m is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and in accordance with the recommended height in Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD. The proposed depth of the extension and materials would remain the same as per the approved scheme. The proposed fixed and obscure glazed windows to the side elevation, due to their size and design are considered to be acceptable.The proposed alterations to the side dormers in terms of their design and slight changes in their siting and size, due to their modest scale are considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. Officers note no changes in terms of design, siting  or volume to the approved piggy back extension, which is considered not to be materially different to the consented scheme.As such, it is considered that due to the modest scale of the proposed alterations and their siting, there would be no adverse impact on the character and appearance of the host dwelling and the surrounding area. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers note the concerns raised within the written representations regarding the loss of daylight, loss of privacy and overbearing appearance as a result of the proposal. It is considered that the increase in height of the extension (approximately 0.5m) given its siting in relation to the existing rear building line at No 91A would not materially impact on the light and outlook in relation to the adjoining properties compared with the consented scheme.The alterations to the siting and size of the side dormers, due to their modest scale and obscure and non openable windows below 1.7m when measured from the floor level, are also not considered to materially impact on  light conditions and outlook compared with the previous consented scheme ref 22/02784/HOU.The replacement of the Juliet balcony with a window in the rear elevation, would result in a smaller opening, it is not considered to have materially different impact when compared with the previous scheme. With regards to the potential overlooking, a relevant condition would be added for any proposed windows and rooflights above the ground floor level in side elevations to be obscure glazed and non-openable below 1.7m when measured from the floor level. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a first floor flat in a three storey detached building.  The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Erection of rear roof terrace and all associated works at Flat 3.Consultations27 properties were notified of the proposal. Three representations have been received objecting to the proposal, with comments summarised as follows:- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/Sunlight- Noise- PrivacyOne neutral comment has been received regarding lack of structural calculations Officer comment: Any matters controlled under non-planning laws such as building regulations or problems arising from the construction period are not material planning considerations and they cannot be included within the assessment.Other concerns will be addressed with this report. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: From the character and appearance perspective, the proposed balcony and patio door, given its siting, scale and design is considered to be in-keeping with the host building. Offices note the existing balcony that serves the other first floor flat. The proposal would not be visible from Fassett Road, therefore it would not have an impact on the existing street scene. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is noted that the previous application ref 23/01587/FUL was refused on 29.08.2023 due to the following reasons:1. The proposed development by virtue of its siting and design would give rise to a loss of privacy to neighbouring occupiers both within the residential block the application site forms part of and at the adjacent residential block causing harm to the existing living conditions of the neighbouring occupiers. The proposal therefore would not accord with policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.2. The applicant has failed to demonstrate that the proposed development would not result in noise and disturbance to the residential unit directly below and would not as result cause undue harm to the neighbouring occupiers living conditions. The proposal therefore would not accord with policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.Officers note concerns received within written representation regarding the potential loss of privacy and undue overlooking as a result of the proposal.To address the first reason for refusal the applicant proposes an approximately 1.8m high opaque glazed screen to the side elevation of the balcony. The submitted drawing 182490-01-208D Overlooking Areas shows typical existing and proposed overlooking areas, which would not be significantly changed. However, it is considered that the proposed approximately 1m high clear balustrade to the front would allow for additional undue overlooking.Officers note the planning permission ref  18/12647/FUL for 'Formation of a first floor roof terrace for Flat D, enclosed by 1.8m high privacy screen' granted on 12.10.2018 which seems to be implemented but not according to conditions, which may result in an enforcement action. While roof terraces/balconies are generally not supported as they often give rise to issues of overlooking/loss of privacy to adjoining properties, in this case the proposal could be acceptable subject to all the balcony screens being approximately 1.7m high and obscure glazed. With regards to the second reason for refusal, the applicant indicates that proposal would be carried out in accordance with building regulations relating to sound and load and there is a similar existing balcony at the adjoining property. As some flats at 48 Fassett Road benefit from either patio area or a balcony and considering the modest scale of the proposal, it is considered that it would not result in material increase in noise or disturbance.It is further noted that the Environmental Protection Act (1990) provides controls to the Council in the event that any noise should occur that could constitute a statutory nuisance. Due to the scale and siting of the proposal it is considered that it would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight in relation to habitable openings at the adjoining properties. Overall, it is considered that the proposal would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, undue overlooking or loss of privacy subject to a condition relating to all the sides of the balcony being approximately 1.7m high and obscure glazed. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Planning Fire Safety Strategy, which is considered to be acceptable. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The Root Identification survey 11/12/2023 states only oak and sweet chestnut roots found. No yew roots have been identified below the foundations of the building. The readings are moving up in winter and down in summer consistent with subsidence.The identification of oak roots implicates either the neighbouring oak tree T1 or the holm oak within part of the hedge H1. Neither of these trees are protected by a Tree Preservation Order or situated within a Conservation Area. The Council would raise no objection to the removal of the neighbouring oak tree or the holm oak within part of the hedge and work can take place without the specific consent of the Local Planning Authority.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling. Consultations6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.Relevant Planning History- 24/00728/PAEXT - Erection of single storey rear extension (6m in depth, maximum height of 3m and eaves height of 2.77m). Prior Approval Refused on 03.05.2024 for the following reason:1) The assessment has been based on the original layout of the house that shows a staggered rear elevation. The proposed extension would extend beyond the side elevation and would  have a width greater than half the width of the original dwellinghouse, in conflict with Paragraph A.1 (j) (iii) of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).- 21/02974/PAEXT - Erection of single storey rear extension (5.30m in depth, maximum height of 3.20m and eaves height of 3.20m). Prior Approval Refused on 22.10.2021 for the following reasons:1) The eaves of the proposed rear extension would exceed the height of the eaves of the existing dwellinghouse, in conflict with Paragraph A.1 (d) of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).2)The proposed rear extension would extend beyond a wall forming a side elevation of the original dwellinghouse, and would have a width greater than half the width of the original dwellinghouse, in conflict with Paragraph A.1 (j) (iii) of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development.- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire Safety.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The single-storey rear extension would have a slightly pitched roof with total height of approximately 3m with an eave height of approximately 2.7m. Additionally, the proposed development would not be visible from the streetscene and subordinate and proportionate to the existing dwelling.Therefore, the proposed extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities. Given the proximity of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: Although the applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances / an evacuation assembly point could be secured by condition, and Officers consider that the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A) could be secured through condition. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2023), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan 2021, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2022 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe site comprises a mid terrace dwelling. Consultations3 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. No  letters of representation were received.  Proposal The application seeks full planning permission for the erection of a single storey rear extension and installation 3nos front and 3 nos rear rooflights.Planning Assessment  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire Safety DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposal seeks approval  for the erection of a single storey rear extension and installation of  3 nos front and 3 nos rear rooflights.The existing dwelling  has an existing three storey  outrigger (ground, first and second floors) beyond which is a single storey w/c and storage  brick structure with a single aspect corrugated iron roof with an eaves height 2.617m and pitch height 2675m.  The proposed single storey rear extension would extend a depth of 6.502m from the original  rear elevation of the existing dwelling and 2.5m from the single storey brick structure attached to the outrigger.Officers note the  proposed new rear building line would be in alignment with the existing rear building line with neighbouring no 71 Burlington Road.  It would have a  proposed width of 4.602m  with the built form positioned hard up against the shared site boundary. The proposed single storey rear extension would have a parapet roof with a height of 3.3m. The proposed rear elevation would accommodate a set of patio doors. In terms of proposed materials and finishes, the walls would be constructed in mixed facing brick to match existing ; the roof would comprise of a flat roof system; windows upvc to match existing and doors would be upvc and timber.Officers acknowledge that the depth of the overall  proposed extension would not comply with the guidelines in the Residential Design SPD. Policy Guidance 33 which recommends a total depth of 3.5m for terrace dwellings. There are no other examples within this terraced residential block.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered unacceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design . It is considered that there would be an unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers have assessed the impact on daylight  of the proposed rear extension using BRE45 degree rule and the Residential Design to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities. In this instance, an assessment has been  undertaken in respect of neighbouring no 67 Burlington Road. Given the siting and depth of the proposed development hard on the boundary, it is considered that the proposed development would result in the significant loss of daylight to the closest habitable room at ground level in comparison with the existing situation.Thereby it would adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers.Due to its siting and depth the proposed development  along the shared boundary with no 67, it is considered that the proposed development would constitute an unneighbourly form of development and present and overbearing appearance in this location. Overall, given the size of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring property of no 67, it is considered that the proposed development would adversely affect the amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The application seeks approval of the details required by Condition 4 (Fire safety) of planning permission 22/02606/FUL.The wording of Condition 4 (Fire safety) of planning permission 22/02606/FUL.Prior to any above ground works (excluding demolition) a Fire Safety Strategy shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The Fire Safety Strategy shall demonstrate how the development will achieve the highest standards of fire safety and shall include the following details: 1) suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point; 2) Appropriate fire alarm systems; 3) Passive and active fire safety measures; 4) appropriate construction details to minimise the risk of fire spread; 5) provision of suitable and convenient means of escape/ an evacuation strategy;6) provision of suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development. The Fire Safety Strategy shall include a statement of competence. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Strategy and thereafter maintained. Reason: In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users in accordance with Policy D12 (Fire safety) of the London Plan 2021.The applicant has deposited a fire safety strategy.The details have been reviewed  and officers are satisfied that in the context of the proposed development and the site the details meet the requirements for condition 4 of planning permission 22/02606/FUL.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that condition 4 of planning permission 22/02606/FUL are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe application site contains a seven storey building (Esher Wing), located to west of the hospital site (Kingston Hospital). Esher Wing is located closest to Wolverton Avenue.The application site falls within the Wolverton Avenue Local Area of Special Character and Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. Proposal (Retrospective) Erection of a chiller plant room on the existing roof of Esher Wing Building and a new AHU plant room on the existing roof of the Esher Wing Building to serve the Medical Day Unit (MDU) on level 6. ConsultationsDue to the size and siting of the application site, 4 site notices have been displayed to notify the adjoining properties about the proposal. No representations were received.  The Council's Environmental Health Officer - no objections. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the Heritage Assets; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.Character and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed plant enclosures, installation of air source heat pump and raised decking to the rooftop, given their size, siting and the proposed design are considered to be in keeping with the host building and the other existing plant enclosures. It is considered that the proposal would not be visually intrusive and would not detract from the character and appearance of the host building or surrounding area. Non-Designated Heritage AssetsParagraphs 200 to 204 of the NPPF 2023 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Paragraph 209 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.The application site falls within the Wolverton Avenue Local Area of Special Character and Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character  which is a non-designated heritage asset. As stated above Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in an adverse impact to the host building or the character and appearance of the surrounding area. It follows that Officers consider that the proposed development would  not result in harm to the significance of Wolverton Avenue Local Area of Special Character and Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposal and its modest scale, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance,  an unacceptable increase in noise levels, loss of light or loss of privacy, subject to compliance within the submitted External Plant Noise Assessment. It is noted that the Council's Environmental Health Officer raised no objections to the proposal. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Condition 4 (Fire Safety Statement) of planning permission 23/01556/FUL states:Prior to beneficial use of the development to which this permission relates, a Fire Safety Strategy shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The Fire Safety Strategy shall demonstrate how the development will achieve the highest standards of fire safety and shall include the following details:1) suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point;2) Appropriate fire alarm systems;3) Passive and active fire safety measures;4) appropriate construction details to minimise the risk of fire spread;5) provision of suitable and convenient means of escape/ an evacuation strategy;6) provision of suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development. The Fire Safety Strategy shall include a statement of competence.The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Strategy and thereafter maintained.The required Fire Safety Strategy shall reference the London Plan Guidance Fire Safety (February 2022),  where applicable and a Reasonable Exception Statement (RES) shall be submitted in relation to those fire safety requirements which the applicant does not consider to be relevant.Reason: In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users in accordance with Policy D12 (Fire safety) of the London Plan 2021.Officer Comment: The submitted by the applicant Cover Letter dated 21.03.2024 and the drawing KM/SP/001 are considered to be acceptable, as such the details submitted in relation to Condition 4 are hereby approved.

Condition 14 (Construction Management Plan) - RBK Neighbourhood engineer has reviewed the information submitted and is not satisfied this can be discharged.The Construction Management Plan (CMP) contains most of the requirements listed except for the following observations, which needs to be addressed:Item (V) - The applicant should consider re-timing deliveries to the site to take place during the offpeak periods of the agreed working hours. This is to ensure minimal disruption to the local traffic;Item (XI) - The contractor (or relevant utility company) will have to apply for a Section 50 Street works Licence, which will authorise them to place their apparatus within the public highway and carry out statutory undertaker connections to relevant utilities;With respect to items XII, XV & XVIII, a construction site layout, which will show the proposed onsite car parking for contractor staff/operatives, storage area for work materials and other ancillary site buildings, has not been provided by the applicant. This would be required in the CMP; To prevent any pressure on the local residents car parking spaces, no construction related vehicle should be parked on any part of the highway in the residential area;According to the applicant, vehicles can access the site through Manor Drive North from the left and Malden Road on the right. Preferably, construction traffic should be restricted to the use of A2043 Malden Road only, to access the site location on Church Road. Furthermore, the applicant has not provided a map, which will show the routing of construction vehicles to the site. This would be required as part of the CMP; and The CMP should provide an indication of the size of construction vehicles expected at the site during the stages of site development works and their respective frequencies.

Application SiteThe site comprises a ground floor commercial unit within a two storey terrace.ProposalAlterations to fenestrations to ground floor rear and sideConsultation12 neighbours have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed changes to fenestrations is to the rear of the property. The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers note the introduction of a window to the side elevation but it will face a soild flank elevation without windows. Overall,  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.
